clinical_study.brief_title: Genotypic Resistance Guided Therapy in Helicobacter Pylori Eradication
clinical_study.official_title: Genotypic Resistance Guided Therapy in the Treatment of Helicobacter Pylori Infection

brief_summary.textblock: We aimed to compare the efficacy of genotypic resistance guided sequential therapy vs. empiric therapy in the third line therapy. Factors affecting the eradication rates, including the antibiotic resistance, CYP2C19 polymorphism, CagA and VacA status will also be assessed.

detailed_description.textblock: The primary aim of this study is to compare the regimens selected using either one of the method (1) genotypic resistance guided versus (2) medication history guided therapy. (rather than to compare the efficacy of any drugs).

primary_outcome.measure: Eradication rate after third line rescue therapy
primary_outcome.description: Primary End Point: Eradication rate will be evaluated according to Intent-to-treat (ITT) and per-protocol (PP) analyses. (genotypic resistance versus empirical therapy) Urea breath test will be used to determine the eradication status

secondary_outcome.measure: eradication rates in subgroup analysis by antibiotic resistance and regimen
secondary_outcome.description: eradication rate in subgroup analysis according to antibiotic resistance and treatment regimen

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged greater than 20 years who have persistent H. pylori infection after at least two treatments and are willing to receive third line rescue regimens are considered eligible for enrollment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients will be excluded from the study if any one of the following criteria is present: (1) children and teenagers aged less than 20 years, (2) history of gastrectomy, (3)gastric malignancy, including adenocarcinoma and lymphoma, (4) previous allergic reaction to antibiotics (Amoxicillin, Klaricid, Cravit) and prompt pump inhibitors (esomeprazole), (5)contraindication to treatment drugs, (6) pregnant or lactating women, (7) severe concurrent disease.
